import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = [10, 5]

pass_mark = 60
source.75dfda52:
print('Male:',len(df[df.gender == 'male']))
print('Female:',len(df[df.gender == 'female']))
y = np.array([len(df[df.gender == 'male']),len(df[df.gender == 'female'])])
x = ["Male","Female"]
plt.bar(x,y)
plt.title("Gender Representation")
plt.xlabel("Gender")
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.show()

df['College'] = 'Degree'

source.1915a82e:
Things to work on in the future:
1. Regression models to estimate test scores.
2. Classificaiton models to estimate if students pass.
3. Run Clustering algorithms to see variable relations.
source.5bbabd5c: Next we look at the subset of students who failed each test (failing grade of 60) and see if we have any interesting insights.
source.45a28758: We see there's a majority of parents who haven't finished college
source.231dc073: We see that on average students who recieve free/reduced lunch have lower test scores for all three subjects compared to students who pay standard price for lunch. This may stem from a connection of lower income household leading to lower test scores.
source.36a5c104: Quick look to see how the data is formatted
source.f2a47779: Again, we see that the distribution has swapped from the full data set, showing that students who fail are more likely to be on a free/reduce lunch payment.
source.01812d26: I understand free/reduced lunch payment as typically being associated with lower income so we may be able to use this as a proxy for parent's income
source.ba6bfef3: We see that certain demographic and economic variables like gender, parent's education, and a proxy for household income has an affect on test scores.
source.9c9af0ba: Men do better in math while women do better in reading and writing. An interesting insight is the downside variation in womens' test scores. Not sure what the cause of this could be.
source.b1e0677b: We see that, on average, students whose parents have a college degree do better on each test
source.1d55058b: Furthermore, we see that will parent's education the majority grows when looking at students who failed.
source.a5887026: It seems the correlations break down a little bit within this subset
source.d9f77693: Hard to see the exact difference between finished college and not so we'll dig in a little more
source.d62e4601: Check to see if any variables have NA data
source.d2907dd4: ### Import Data and take a quick look
source.378e6d4e: Rename the dataframe columns to make it easier for referencing
source.bc78fc11: We see here that although for the entire dataset it's a slight majority to female but students who failed all the tests has a decent majority to men.
source.019d2033: Use pass_mark of 60 due to it being the typical failing grade for US High schools.
source.0407c2cb: We see that reading and writing have quite a tight corrleation while math and reading/writing is slightly looser
